iv'e been seeing a lot of pro-war statements lately.
 
 "saddam is evil."
 
 "iraq must be liberated; the pain they go through."
 
 "we must back up america."
 
 ok, maybe saddam is "evil", but do you really think iraq has the most repressive government in the world? do we really care about the lives of the "poor iraqis"? just because america says so, does that mean we have to follow?
 
 the answer is no.
 
 i mean come on people, we all noticed the sudden pro-american attitude after 9/11. no one could care less before and out of nowhere, we are patriotic.
 
 posing? i think so.
 
 the funny thing is, america is posing; politicians included. they see an oppritunity to steal from a country; they take it. bush is playing on the emotions of the american people.
 
 does he care about the lives of the american soldiers? no.
 
 bush is sending thousands of soldiers to iraq to "liberate" the people. uh huh, i bet oil has no issue in this war. it was even said "after we win the war, we will take the amount of oil we had to use during the war." i'm sure america will take the exact amount... i can see it now; we take the amont needed, then we overstay our welcome; suck up iraq's oil; take over the oil fields; and when we are done, leave them to rot with nothing.
 
 the war is supposed to be to "stop civilian murdering". the funny thing is though, our soldiers kill civilians and then they say "well, there are bound to be civilian casualties." if that is so, why even go to war in the first place? we are doing saddam's job for him.
 
 politics is war without bloodshed; war is politics with bloodshed. you have heard that politicians are corrupt right? so is this war. it is run by the corrupt.
 
 the american people are clueless; me included. much is censored.
 
 i probably have much more to say; i am just leaving now, bye.

post_info.post_title: i'm tired of the pro-war posers

Considering Iraqi terror ties, WMD in this time, I would disagree. President Bush is, in my opinion, attempting to secure America. 
 
 To solve the terrorist problem, we must solve the problems that create them. Repression and the harsh lives people live in the Middle East is usually what leads to hatred of the West. We have so much, and they have so little, and we do nothing. 
 
 But that will soon stop. The regimes in Iraq, Syria, Iran, and Lebanon must be destroyed. We must spread democracy, we must eliminate a need for sanctions, we must invest in creating a better life for the people that live in those places. 
 
 This is only the beginning.
How about North Korea? They are the BIGGEST threat.
But right now, we trust the North Koreans to not use the weapons, even if they do have them. We DON'T trust Saddam to not use his weapons, because he already has.

It's news to me that we ever trusted North Korea. I think a primary reason we are pursuing Saddam and not Kim is that North Korea could actually fight back. They actually HAVE weapons of mass destruction, and the means to use them.

DownWithDubya-
 
 
How about North Korea? They are the BIGGEST threat.

 
 North Korea is nothing. In fact, I think their quest for world attention is quite pathetic.
 
 thistownwilleat-
 
 
It's news to me that we ever trusted North Korea. I think a primary reason we are pursuing Saddam and not Kim is that North Korea could actually fight back. They actually HAVE weapons of mass destruction, and the means to use them.

 
 See above. Kim isn't interested in fighting, he just wants himself and his country to be in the news again. He's just like a fat weakling, he acts big, but he's really puny and pathetic. Besides, if he does try something stupid, we not only have South Korea and Japan right next to him, but I'm sure we could convince China to tell him to shut the hell up.
China already did tell NKorea to shut up. They shut off some oil flow.
but the fact of the matter is, EVERY COUNTRY HAS WEAPONS OF MASS DESTUCTION.

Crim-
 
 
China already did tell NKorea to shut up. They shut off some oil flow.

 
 Ouch. Is that a little smartness I smell in your comment? Oh, please... do bring more. Your friend XYOU claims America would have a difficult time fighting against China, so obviously the can do more than shut off some oil, no? Oh, but wait. North Korea is actually opposing the Great Satan, so I guess, the brainwashed Chinese would have no problem with that.

Heres what I think:
 
 so osama wasnt found in afginistan. ever since 9/11 the war on terror has been a main concern among many. bush wants to keep the war on terror up and running. who better to blame than saddam for a new fight? he likes to keep the american people happy knowing that the war on terror is still being fought, and im pretty sure that once the war in iraq is over, we will turn to some other harmless country and "liberate" it. bush had an 80 something % approval after his speach describing the war on terror after 9/11. so why not try and boost those ratings again?? fight iraq to make the people think that terrorists are weakenening, even when iraq has little to do with it. so far it is working with bush having approval ratings of nothing less than 60
 
 so anyone who thinks this war is over oil is wrong. ive heard some say the war is over oil to boost the economy. but will cheaper oil prices boost the economy more than a war will hurt it?? i think not
 
 and so why would bush want oil for the country??? the money dosent go to him. and so what if both the president and vice president have oil company backgrounds(i dont know the details) does anyone think that because of this they are oil greedy???
 
 tell me what you think

first off, the war on terrorism is pointless. this war is ongoing. it is like declaring a war against evil. bush just started a war that will never end.
 
 there is no reason for this war. it is to make the american people feel better. america is the aggressor in this case. i'm behind russia and france on this one.
The only reason they oppose the war is because they make billions from Iraq.
so they're greedy; we are murderers.

Ouch. Is that a little smartness I smell in your comment? Oh, please... do bring more. Your friend XYOU claims America would have a difficult time fighting against China, so obviously the can do more than shut off some oil, no? Oh, but wait. North Korea is actually opposing the Great Satan, so I guess, the brainwashed Chinese would have no problem with that.
 
 
 What the hell are you talking about?
 My post gave no support to XYOU.
i know there are bound to be civilian deaths in war, but i see no justification for this war. if there is no justification in my eyes, i see pointless death.

gilligan were you aginst the US going into Afginistan?
 
 if so...
 
 i heard some stupid women on CNN saying we shouldnt have because of the civilian casulities, but does it not occur to some people that in the long run more people will be saved by the US than if they hadnt gone in and people continued to starve.(not applying to iraq)

i don't like the idea of the usa being the world police.
 
 humanitarian aid is okay.
World police? Iraq is a threat.

i wouldnt say that iraq is a treat to the United States, they are a threat to neighbooring countries friendly to us. 
 
 of course if iraq could attack the US directly, im sure saddam would love to

ok, the way i see it is this:
 the usa is attacking iraq because of the POSSIBILITY of a catastrophe.
 
 ever seen the movie minority report? scary huh... but in this case... we can't read minds.

But you have to ask which threat is larger, the threat we face in a dying country run by a dying man on a dying economy and military, or the threat that we will face when we take over the country and inflame the entire Muslim world. Yes, we solve the current problem, but in the long run....

Ha! We're setting up a TV station down there. Change the news from the Israel/ Palestine issue and I doubt many will be angry. 
 
 This is being reported as Israel vs. Palestine, which we all know is absurd. That's why people are angry.

ok, the way i see it is this:
 the usa is attacking iraq because of the POSSIBILITY of a catastrophe. 
 
 
 Yes. We believe Saddam is trying to get or has (or more than likely, both) weapons of mass destruction. We know that he will use them if he feels like it. (Just ask the Kurds. He used them on his own people.) Therefore, we want to make sure that he will be unable to use them on Israel or another ally.
by the way, did you know we have found NO weapons of mass destruction in iraq? funny huh?
True. Even FOX news admits that we have found NO hard evidence of weapons of mass destruction.

We haven't searched the entire country. We haven't even taken control of all the cities. We haven't had time to search for WMD yet. But there is plenty of proof that he has WMD. Take a look at this UK report:
 
 http://www.official-documents.co.uk/document/reps/iraq/contents.htm

of course we haven't found any
 we've given Saddam years of experience in how and where to hide weapons from inspectors
Yeah...well these aren't inspectors, this is an army, not a bunch of pasty scientists with clipboards.
So far, the army hasn't been much worse at finding WMD than the inspectors have.
well at least they got saddam out of main military power. Sorry that i seem so rusty at debating h. I havent done it in a month :(
No one ever questioned on whether we could remove Saddam from power, that's a given. It's the management of the damage we've done in Iraq and around the world that is in question.

What damage around the world? And the Iraqi people love us for freeing them except for a hand full. And the only "damage" we did around the world is we saw who were our true allies and some didnt quite like us. Like France, they betrayed us, not only in trying to stop the war but by making business where business shouldnt be made.

Debategirl, did you know that every major political and religious group are demanding an end to US involvement. Did you know that there are mass demonstrations in the street calling for the end of US occupation? The Shi'ite Muslims, which make up over 60% of Iraq, have DEMANDED that we be out in a month. We are not seen as liberators. You're shown pictures of Saddam statues being pulled down by Iraqi citizens, but you are not shown everything else. Oh, and by the way, the BBC did a little side on the pictures of Saddam's statue being pulled down by the "masses". There were actually only about 2 dozen people, so the photographers zoomed in on them to make it look like a huge crowd. Just another discreet little way you're being lied to.
 
 And what damage???? We have permanantly scarred relations around the world. And your definition of a "true ally" is someone who agrees with you all the time....and to be honest that's really quite stupid. We have no proof of weapons of mass destruction, we never did. Yes Saddam gassed his only people and killed them, and blah blah, but didn't care at the time he did it? Why do we care now? Oh and by the way it is against international law for one country to move into another without proof for a regime change. So basically our the people you say aren't are "true allies" are the people who believe in keeping international law. 
 
 The real damage is that US hatred is blazing across the Middle East. The Muslims in Iraq hate us, and the groups that already hated us now have a new reason to fight. The CIA published a report on terrorists threats in the Middle East that stated terror activity would sky rocket if we invaded Iraq, Iran, or Syria.
 
 Oh, and by the way this war is not about the liberation of the Iraqi people, a country cannot invade another to "free it's people". Iraqi Freedom is just used as a distraction from the real purpose in the war, WMD's. We can't find any so the administration frantically scrambled around to find some other justification for war to spoon feed the people. And it's working. No body cares about WMD's anymore, the plan worked perfectly.

thistownwilleat-
 
 1) I agree, we should move out of Iraq, let Saddam take over again, and let him kill millions more of his own people because of their unfaithfulness to him.
 
 2) CNN has already stated that the anti-Saddam demonstrators weren't huge crowds, but it just looked that way. You should really do some thorough research before resulting to silly bashing.
 
 3) Terror activities in America will skyrocket if we sit around and act like a bunch of sissy babies sucking our thumbs. Regardless of whether or not you want to believe it, terrorists hate pro-Iraqi freedom supporters just as much as they hate anti-Iraqi freedom protestors.
 
 4) What's wrong with freeing the Iraqi people? I know since we're Americans, most of us are a bunch of greedy capitalists, but are we so greedy that we want to keep freedom for ourselves and ignore any country serving under a oppressive government?

Habbit (sigh)....
 
 1. Who said anything about letting Saddam taking over? The point is we don't need full military occupation to control one man. And that's all he is now. He has nothing. No army, nothing. So stop spouting rhetoric. Let a minimal number of special forces and intelligence take Saddam. I'm not saying we move out now...but the Iraqi people aren't stupid, they know we plan on being their for a few years.
 
 2. Silly bashing? I suppose you thought that was clever...how sad. I stated a fact...photographs were manipulated and news was overdone to make it look like all of Iraq was beating on Saddam's door with pitchforks and torches.
 
 3 & 4. The CIA published a report stating that Saddam was only a real potential threat in the event of an invasion. We have NO proof, we have NO evidence, we have NOTHING that warrants a full scale invasion. So we divert attention from weapons of mass destruction and potential threat to "liberating the Iraqi people". I'll bet you a thousand dollars that before FOX news pumped peoples heads full of "Operation Iraqi Freedom", 90% of the American people didn't give a damn about Iraq or anybody in it. The Bush administration manipulated the deaths of 3,000 American citizens to address it's own agenda.

thistownwilleat-
 
 
1. Who said anything about letting Saddam taking over? The point is we don't need full military occupation to control one man. And that's all he is now. He has nothing. No army, nothing. So stop spouting rhetoric. Let a minimal number of special forces and intelligence take Saddam.

 
 1) Thanks for proving my point. The Baath Party regime is not made up of one man.
 2) Many people have tried to kill Saddam, his family, and members of the regime in an effort to end the Baath Party rule. None have succeeded, until now.
 
 
2. Silly bashing? I suppose you thought that was clever...how sad. I stated a fact...photographs were manipulated and news was overdone to make it look like all of Iraq was beating on Saddam's door with pitchforks and torches.

 
 Would 'pathetic bashing' be better? Anyway, back to the main point, (great way of screwing around it, by the way) some of the American news media has already told people that the pictures did not represent 'all of Iraq was beating on Saddam's door with pitchforks and torches'. It's your decision to accept that and leave it alone.
 
 
3 & 4. The CIA published a report stating that Saddam was only a real potential threat in the event of an invasion. We have NO proof, we have NO evidence, we have NOTHING that warrants a full scale invasion. So we divert attention from weapons of mass destruction and potential threat to "liberating the Iraqi people". I'll bet you a thousand dollars that before FOX news pumped peoples heads full of "Operation Iraqi Freedom", 90% of the American people didn't give a damn about Iraq or anybody in it. 

 
 1) I'm not going to get into the part about we having nothing that warrants an attack on Iraq, because that information has already been raped to death. However, what does it matter if the administration changed the reason of the operation? Would you have rather Saddam stay in power?
 2) I bet you a thousand dollars you're right, which proves my point that Americans want freedom, but don't want or care for other countries to possess it. 
 
 
The Bush administration manipulated the deaths of 3,000 American citizens to address it's own agenda.

 
 I assume you're talking about September 11th. If so, is there another discussion thread for conspiracy theories?

Originally posted by Habbit 
 1) Thanks for proving my point. The Baath Party regime is not made up of one man.
 2) Many people have tried to kill Saddam, his family, and members of the regime in an effort to end the Baath Party rule. None have succeeded, until now.
 

 
 Do you think the next regime will be friendly to the US if freely elected?
 
 
Originally posted by Habbit 
  
 However, what does it matter if the administration changed the reason of the operation? 

 
 Yes it does. First reason is: We need clear reasons for going to war, not "change as you go" reasoning. Second: It will be harder in the future for the US to garner support if it is necessary to go to war. No one will believe us. Even the American people will be skeptical.
 
 
Originally posted by Habbit 
  Would you have rather Saddam stay in power?
 

 
 Actually, we might have been better off if free elections are to be held.
 
 
Originally posted by Habbit 
  
 ... Americans want freedom, but don't want or care for other countries to possess it. 

 
 It is not the US's job to insure freedom throughout the world. What kind of freedom? We lose our liberty everyday due to legislation passed by our representatives (gun control, public education, and other legislation). 
 
 I doubt the founders of this country would want this. They were skeptical on us even having a standing military.
 
 Liberals think like you, just through money or American lives at a problem (i.e. foreign dictators) and it will solve it. I disagree.

theLIBERTARIAN-
 
 
Do you think the next regime will be friendly to the US if freely elected?

 
 It depends on the person elected, I guess. I highly doubt that the Iraqi's will elect a person whom the U.S. favors, but I also doubt they'd choose someone who despises this country.
 
 
First reason is: We need clear reasons for going to war, not "change as you go" reasoning.

 
 True, but, liberation of the Iraqi people was just one of the reasons for the war against Iraq. It was not a main reason, but it was still a reason.
 
 
Second: It will be harder in the future for the US to garner support if it is necessary to go to war. No one will believe us. Even the American people will be skeptical.

 
 True.
 
 
It is not the US's job to insure freedom throughout the world. 

 
 It's the job of the U.S. to protect itself from attacks or invasions led by cruel dictators or clandestine terrorist leaders. Proving freedom to a country ruled by a cruel dictator who is also known to have been friendly with terrorists is a way to help with rotection of the U.S.
 
 
What kind of freedom? We lose our liberty everyday due to legislation passed by our representatives (gun control, public education, and other legislation). 
 

 
 We still have our freedom of thought and speech.
 
 
Liberals think like you, just through money or American lives at a problem (i.e. foreign dictators) and it will solve it. I disagree.

 
 Fortunately I am neither liberal nor conservative, I'm in the middle. I agree with you. I don't think we should invade Iran, Syria, or North Korea. (yet)

I never thought we would... I think the administration is going to fund the resistance movements in Syria and Iran... those regimes could fall quickly if we gave them some cash and weapons and did a little air support. North Korea has nuclear weapons... can't invade them, and the only way we can kill Kim is to plant some explosives on some of his women... 
 
 The people of many countries in the Middle East are very Western... they were against the war, but hey, the line for McDonalds in Kuwait City was 2 and a half hours long, and a lot of the Iraqis I saw were drinking Pepsi.

Originally posted by Habbit 
 
 It depends on the person elected, I guess. I highly doubt that the Iraqi's will elect a person whom the U.S. favors, but I also doubt they'd choose someone who despises this country.
 

 
 Unless we monkey with the elections I bet they will elect someone hostile to the US.
 
 
Originally posted by Habbit 
 
 True, but, liberation of the Iraqi people was just one of the reasons for the war against Iraq. It was not a main reason, but it was still a reason.

 
 The liberation of the Iraqi people is the last reason on the list. There are numerous cruel dictators in the world, some even worse (African countries).
 
 
Originally posted by Habbit 
 
 It's the job of the U.S. to protect itself from attacks or invasions led by cruel dictators or clandestine terrorist leaders. Proving freedom to a country ruled by a cruel dictator who is also known to have been friendly with terrorists is a way to help with rotection of the U.S.

 
 We caused 9-11. According to Ossama the attack of 9-11 was in retaliation for our support of Israel and our stationing of troops in Saudi Arabia. Our best "protection" is to worry about ourselves, not get involved in other counties affairs.
 
 
Originally posted by Habbit 
 
 We still have our freedom of thought and speech.

 
 I am against the Patriot and Homeland Security Acts. These two in the long run (10 years or more) could threaten these freedoms.
 
 
Originally posted by Habbit 
 Fortunately I am neither liberal nor conservative, I'm in the middle. I agree with you. I don't think we should invade Iran, Syria, or North Korea. (yet) 

 
 I think Iran will be our next target. I predict more terrorist attacks against the US due to our policies. One good thing though, I hear Ossama is running out of money.
 
 My non-interventionist views goes back to the eighties. I had no idea that our interventionist policies would lead to something as horrific as 9-11. I was a non-interventionist as a matter of principle.

Originally posted by Broker 
 I never thought we would... I think the administration is going to fund the resistance movements in Syria and Iran... those regimes could fall quickly if we gave them some cash and weapons and did a little air support. 

 
 Things like this can backfire. Example: Afghanistan. We supplied the Taliban with stingers and other weapons. Now these stingers were used to shoot down Israeli planes over Africa and could possibly make there way back to the states. Also the CIA was instrumental in Saddam's rise to power. We backed him going back to the early sixties and finally were able to get him in power.
 
 
Originally posted by Broker 
  North Korea has nuclear weapons... can't invade them, and the only way we can kill Kim is to plant some explosives on some of his women... 

 
 I agree. In fact I don't want to back Kim into a corner. I was against Bush including him in the axis of evil. What purpose did his statement make? Right after Bushes proclamation Kim started his nuclear weapons program.
 
 
Originally posted by Broker 
  The people of many countries in the Middle East are very Western... they were against the war, but hey, the line for McDonalds in Kuwait City was 2 and a half hours long, and a lot of the Iraqis I saw were drinking Pepsi. 

 
 That is interesting. They love our Starbucks but hate us. They don't realize that our freedom made all of these great things possible. Good point.
 
 Thanks for the dialog Broker.

Well, it happens. You think they have certain intentions and it's good to support them... we supported Castro at first until he announced he was setting up a communist government. That support can often mean a lot... I say support them, and if they go sour withdraw your support and slap some sanctions on them.
 
 Kim had the program before that. I think that North Korea started a year or two after the 1994 treaty, and it's important to note that UN inspectors were present... well, maybe from when they first agreed on the treaty they were present...and throughout those eight years they missed a nuclear program that resulted in North Korea having two bombs. You can't just start a program and get results in a year or two... if it was that easy we would be in big trouble. 
 
 Yes, I know. I saw some people with anti-American signs in their car and they had Pepsi's in their hands...if only they did get what freedom could do. But I think if we do like we did Germany and Japan, Iraq would be a nice place in ten years. I hope so...

Originally posted by Broker 
 Well, it happens. You think they have certain intentions and it's good to support them... we supported Castro at first until he announced he was setting up a communist government. That support can often mean a lot... I say support them, and if they go sour withdraw your support and slap some sanctions on them. 

 
 This seems like a cycle. We support somebody, they come to power then they turn or we turn and we slap sanctions. Sanctions can and do lead to war. Remember the Shaw of Iran? We helped him come to power. Eventually our puppets are over-thrown, either by us or internally. I say stop meddling. 
 
 
Originally posted by Broker 
  Kim had the program before that. I think that North Korea started a year or two after the 1994 treaty, and it's important to note that UN inspectors were present... well, maybe from when they first agreed on the treaty they were present...and throughout those eight years they missed a nuclear program that resulted in North Korea having two bombs. You can't just start a program and get results in a year or two... if it was that easy we would be in big trouble. 

 
 I agree. He re-started his program after Bushes proclamation.

Well... I'm sure there are a lot of governments that turned out good that we assisted... 
 
 I think he's had it for the past nine years... the IAEA missed it either way, so we can't really be sure.

Originally posted by Broker 
 
 I think he's had it for the past nine years... 
 
 
 The chemicals and biological that the President claimed Saddam had were the same we sold him in the eighties, two decades ago.
 
 Also, just because a country in friendly now doesn't always hold for the future. THink of our kids.
